Camayang 1 Samji Samira Eranda Nikolla ⁎ Department of Chemical Engineering and Materials Science, Wayne State University, Detroit, MI 48202, United States Department of Chemical Engineering and Materials Science Wayne State University Detroit MI 48202 United States Department of Chemical Engineering and Materials Science, Wayne State University, Detroit, MI 48202, United States ⁎ Corresponding author. 1 Equal Contribution. Graphical abstract Shaping the energy landscape through development of more efficient electrochemical energy conversion and storage devices requires significant advancements in the catalysis of key electrochemical processes involving oxygen. This is especially the case for the oxygen evolution reaction (OER), which is largely challenged by the cost-ineffectiveness of the best performing electrocatalysts (i.e., Ru, Ir), along with their limited stability under acidic conditions. This presents a roadblock in the development of robust acid-based polymer exchange membrane electrochemical systems, currently the most advanced technologies for electrochemical energy conversion. Approaches such as dilution of Ru/Ir into flexible mixed metal oxide frameworks have been used as alternative strategies in designing robust OER electrocatalysts. Herein, we discuss the state of research in this area and detail the effect of the composition and structure of mixed metal oxides on their acidic OER activity and stability. Future directions for developing mixed metal oxide electrocatalysts suitable for acidic electrochemical environments are devised. Keywords Acidic oxygen evolution reaction Mixed metal oxides Perovskites Pyrochlore oxides Ruddlesden-Popper oxides 1 Introduction Shifting the current energy landscape toward renewable sources will require significant action in the development of sustainable energy conversion and storage technologies, including fuel cells, electrolyzers, and metal-air batteries [1–5]. These devices effectively convert, and store intermittent electrical energy generated from renewable sources (i.e., solar and wind) in the form of chemical bonds in molecules through targeted electrochemical reactions [6–8]. For instance, key electrochemical reactions for water splitting in electrolyzers include: (i) the anodic oxygen evolution reaction (OER) leading to the generation of gas-phase oxygen (O2(g)), protons, and electrons from water [9], and (ii) the cathodic hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) leading to the reduction of protons to gas-phase hydrogen (H2(g)) [10]. In a fuel cell, these reactions are reversed, and the chemical energy stored in the form of bonds in fuels (i.e., H2) is converted back to electrical energy [11]. Key electrochemical reactions in fuel cells include: (i) the hydrogen oxidation reaction (HOR) leading to generation of protons and electrons from H2(g), and (ii) the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) which involves reduction of molecular oxygen to water in the presence of electrons and protons. Among these electrochemical reactions, the ones involving oxygen (i.e., OER, ORR) often contribute to significant energy losses within the electrochemical cell [12–15]. This is caused by the higher overpotentials (>0.32 V) required to drive OER/ORR as opposed to those (>0.10 V) required to drive HER/HOR [16–19]. The overpotential is the difference between the thermodynamic potential (i.e., 1.23 V vs. reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) for water splitting) and the potential required to overcome kinetic barriers and drive an electrochemical reaction. Hence, lowering the overpotential via improving the kinetics of these reactions can significantly enhance the overall electrochemical energy conversion and storage in fuel cells and electrolyzers. The design of catalysts for oxygen electrocatalysis is generally influenced by the nature of the electrolyte, which often challenges their stability [20]. The nature of the electrolyte is dictated by the type of charged species that it must conduct to complete the electrocatalytic cycle. Electrolytes are often classified based on their pH as alkaline or acid electrolytes. Acid-based, proton exchange membranes (PEMs) are the most advanced membrane electrolyte systems for fuel cells and electrolyzers [7,21]. They can produce high current densities due to reduced ohmic losses from advancements in thin membrane fabrication while minimizing fuel crossover [7]. PEM electrolyzers are also best suited for intermittent operation, which is key when functioning with renewable energy sources (e.g. solar, wind) [22]. Furthermore, PEMs are resistant to carbon dioxide (CO2) poisoning, which is a significant challenge for alkaline electrolytes, as ambient CO2 reacts with the electrolyte forming carbonates that precipitate and lower the ionic conductivity [23]. With the significant advancements in PEMs, the progress of acid-based electrochemical systems primarily rests on the effective design of catalysts at the electrodes, especially those associated with catalyzing oxygen-based electrochemical reactions (ORR/OER) [24]. Among them, OER presents the largest challenge, due to poor long-term performance of the current state-of-the-art electrocatalysts [24,25]. Rutile oxides of 4d/5d transition metals, such as Ru and Ir, are by far the most studied electrocatalysts for OER in acid media due to the inherent promising activity of these metals [17,25]. Generally, RuO2 has been shown to exhibit high activity but low stability due to the extensive dissolution of Ru. This is caused by the fact that the OER onset potential on this oxide coincides with the onset potential for Ru corrosion [26,27]. Conversely, IrO2 exhibits the best compromise between activity and stability [20]. However, even this oxide is confronted with degradation issues limiting long-term durability. A recent survey among commercial Ir-based catalysts showed that IrO2 lost ~ 35% of its initial mass activity after ~ 13.5 h of chronoamperometry at 1.6 V vs. RHE [28]. The loss of mass activity was attributed to the phase transition from IrO2 to acid soluble Ir forms (e.g., IrO4 2-) at potentials higher than 1.6 V vs. RHE, consistent with other reports on similar oxides [29,30]. In addition to stability, reduction of Ir loading in current electrolyzers is also considered an important bottleneck for water splitting. This stems from the fact that current Ir global supply presents a roadblock in large-scale implementation of PEM electrolyzers [31]. With the PEM electrolyzer technology projected to fully mature in the coming decade, the demand for PEM electrolyzers, and thus Ir as the current state-of-the-art catalyst, is expected to take a steep increase (ca. 50%) [22,32]. A potential approach in reducing Ir loading in PEM electrolyzers involves its dilution in mixed metal oxides. In addition to diluting Ir, the oxide framework presents opportunities to generate catalytic active sites that are electronically and geometrically different from those of IrO2, which could potentially lead to enhanced activity and stability. In the case of acid OER mechanism, two possible four-electron transfer mechanisms for acid OER on oxide electrocatalysts have been proposed. One is the adsorbate evolution mechanism (AEM) with the catalytic cycle illustrated in Scheme 1 a [17,24,33]. The first step involves water dissociation to a proton (H+) and adsorbed OH on a surface metal cation, which further dissociates to adsorbed O in the second step. The adsorbed O reacts with another water molecule to form adsorbed OOH on a surface metal cation in the third step leading to evolution of O2(g). Isotopic labelling experiments have demonstrated that for certain mixed metal oxide electrocatalysts, lattice oxygen can participate in the OER catalytic cycle [34]. Based on this, a second four-electron transfer mechanism known as the lattice oxygen participation mechanism (LOM) with the catalytic cycle illustrated in Scheme 1b has been proposed [35,36]. In LOM, the first two steps involve water dissociation to adsorbed O on a surface lattice O, followed by O2(g) evolution via its coupling with a surface lattice O generating a surface oxygen vacancy in the third step. In the last two steps, this surface oxygen vacancy is filled through water dissociation. From these mechanisms, it is clear that the binding strengths of the oxygen-containing intermediates play an important role in controlling the energetics of the elementary steps and consequently the OER activity. Descriptors related to the surface binding energy of these intermediates (i.e., OH* or the binding difference between O* and OH*) to predict activity have been developed, suggesting that tuning the intermediate binding on the catalyst surface via catalyst compositional or structural modulation could be an effective approach for designing efficient OER electrocatalysts [17,37]. However, as discussed in detail below, these descriptors often fail due to the dynamic nature of the oxide surfaces under acid OER conditions. In this Mini-review, the current advances in acid OER using mixed metal oxide electrocatalysts are summarized. Effects from oxide composition and crystal-structure on the activity and stability are discussed. It is found that this area of research is largely dominated by Ir and Ru based mixed metal oxides, calling for future directions involving non-Ir/Ru based mixed metal oxide catalytic systems. Furthermore, the need for establishing benchmarking protocols and performance metrics for determining the activity and stability of these electrocatalysts is highlighted. A comprehensive analysis of the reported knowledge is used to devise future research directions in assessing the full potential of these electrocatalysts for catalyzing OER in acidic conditions. 2 Mixed metal oxide electrocatalysts 2.1 Modified RuO2 and IrO2 electrocatalysts Incorporating a secondary earth-abundant metal (i.e., Cr, Co, Ni, Zn, and Sn) in rutile RuO2 and IrO2 has been widely explored as an approach to decrease the total Ru/Ir content in these oxides and improve the electrocatalyst performance for acid OER [38–42]. It was reported that incorporating Sn in IrO2 within a range of 0–80 atomic% had limited effect on the OER activity in 0.5 M H2SO4 [42]. Conversely, enhanced OER activity was observed for Ni modified IrO2 in 0.1 M HClO4 [39]. A volcano relation between the Ni concentration and the OER activity was reported with the maximum activity observed for oxides containing Ni in the range of 67–79 atomic%, as shown in Fig. 1 a [39]. To understand the factors that govern the enhanced OER activity, bulk and surface structures of Ir-Ni mixed oxides were studied. A bulk phase transition from a rutile (21 atomic% Ni), a brucite-like (39 atomic% Ni), to a bunsenite (89 atomic% Ni) structure was observed as the Ni concentration increased. It was found that the Ni content in the bulk and near the surface region was similar in all the as-prepared samples. However, after OER testing, regardless of the initial Ni concentration in the oxide, only ~12 atomic% of Ni (relative to the total amount of Ni and Ir in the oxide) remained in the oxide due to Ni leaching (Fig. 1b). While the atomic% of Ni post OER was similar in all systems, differences in their electrochemical performances suggested variations in the nature of the resulting active surface structures. In general, it was suggested that Ni acted as the sacrificial oxide component in that its leaching led to enhanced OER activity through the formation of active OH-containing surface structures, as depicted in Fig. 1c. This was supported by the correlation of the OER activity with the fraction of OH on the surface determined using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). Although the OER activity was improved via Ni incorporation in IrO2, the stability of the Ir-Ni mixed oxide was lower than that of pure IrO2. This was a consequence of the enhanced Ir leaching as a function of Ni content (Fig. 1d). For instance, the Ir leaching rate was reported to be ~47 times higher for the most active Ir0.21Ni0.79O2 as compared to pure IrO2. For Ni modified RuO2, a similar Ni-content dependent activity was reported for OER in 0.1 M HClO4 [43]. It was shown that the OER activity increased with an increase in Ni content from 2 to 30 atomic%. In the case of Ru1-xCrxO2 (x = 0.60–0.91) oxides, the opposite effect was reported (the activity decreased with an increase in Cr content), however, this could have stemmed from the higher Cr concentration in the oxide (60–91 atomic%) when compared to Ni (2–30 atomic%) [38]. It was reported that high Cr content in RuO2 resulted in mixed oxide phases with an inner Cr2O3 core. In the case of Ru1-xCrxO2 (x < 0.67), the formation of phase pure rutile-type mixed oxide decreased the thermodynamic barrier (by ~ 0.1 eV) for the potential determining step in AEM (formation of surface adsorbed OOH) via Cr-induced altering of the Ru electronic structure, leading to high electrochemical rates. For Ru1-xCoxO2 (x < 0.3) oxides, it was reported that the effect of Co-substitution on the OER activity was limited, unlike in the case of Ni around the same compositional range [44]. Interestingly, Co modified RuO2 led to high selectivity toward OER when other parallel reactions were in play, such as the chlorine evolution reaction (CER) during direct seawater electrolysis; a behavior similar to that observed for Zn modified RuO2 [40,44,45]. In general, while incorporation of inexpensive secondary transition metals in IrO2 and RuO2 has shown some promise in improving the OER activity/selectivity of these oxides, conclusive performance trends for this class of oxides are obscured by limited systematic studies. Current reports mainly focus on a very narrow, inconsistent compositional space, due to challenges with achieving phase-pure oxide structures as a function of the nature and concentration of the secondary metal. 2.2 Perovskite electrocatalysts Simple perovskites (ABO3; A = rare earth/alkaline earth; B = transition metal) with mixed ionic-electronic conducting properties are among the most commonly investigated mixed metal oxides for acid OER [46–50]. Perovskites can accommodate > 90% metals in the periodic table in their A- and B-sites, resulting in a large space for tuning their OER activity via changing their composition. It is generally reported that perovskites with Ru and Ir as the B-site cations are the most promising [46,48,50]. However, direct comparison of the performance of various oxides is often challenged by lack of standardized metrics for reporting activity and stability. The OER activities of these oxides are generally reported as the overpotential required to achieve a current density of 10 mA/cm2 geo (“geo” denotes the geometric area of the working electrode). One concern with such approach is the normalization of the current by the geometric surface area of the electrode, which does not account for the actual catalyst active surface area. The ideal approach to address this is to identify ways to determine the electrochemical active surface area (ECSA) of the electrodes, which is a significant challenge for oxide-based composite electrodes [5]. However, it has been shown that normalization per BET (Bremmer-Emmet-Teller) oxide surface area provides an alternate measure of the intrinsic electrochemical activity of the oxide [5,28]. As illustrated in Table 1 , the trends observed using normalization of the measured currents per electrode geometric areas vary significantly in comparison with those per oxide BET surface areas. Thus, consistent normalization of currents per oxide BET surface area should be standardized in the literature for proper determination of the intrinsic activity of mixed metal oxides for acid OER. Independent of these inconsistencies, some general trends can be extracted. For example, modifying the B-site composition of Ir-based perovskites with another heteroatom significantly affects their OER performance [48]. It was shown that SrCo0.9Ir0.1O3 exhibited a 15-fold increase in current density (mA/cm2 oxide, BET) at 1.50 V vs. RHE as compared to unmodified SrIrO3 [48,49]. The enhanced activity was attributed to the low surface oxygen vacancy formation energy and high oxygen vacancy concentration in the oxide crystal lattice due to the under-coordination of the Ir atoms in the IrO6 octahedra. While promising with respect to providing enhanced activity through the use of non-precious transition metal cations in the B-site to dilute Ir content, these oxides were challenged by surface reconstruction during the initial stages of the electrocatalytic testing. The formation of a stable Ir-rich layer over time was reported to contribute to the improved OER activity [49]. In the case of A-site compositional effects on the OER performance of perovskites, it was reported that incorporation of small amounts of Na+ into SrRuO3 (i.e., Sr1-xNaxRuO3; x = 0.05, 0.1) resulted in a 19-fold improvement in the OER activity per BET-normalized current density at 1.5 V vs. RHE (Table 1) [47]. Additionally, the enhancement in the oxide stability was also observed with Sr0.90Na0.10RuO3 retaining 100% of its initial activity by the time SrRuO3 lost 50% of its initial activity [47]. The improved stability was attributed to the distortion of RuO6 octahedra and a shift in dissolution potentials of the A-site cations toward more positive values, decreasing the probability of dissolution of these metal cations under OER potentials. These results present opportunities for future research on improving the stability of Ru-based mixed metal oxides, which are inherently more active and less expensive than their Ir counterparts, through tuning the energetics of ion dissolution by varying the oxide composition [47,52–54]. In addition to the flexible compositions, perovskites exhibit versatile crystal structures that also significantly affect their electrocatalytic performance [46,48–50]. Among these, the 6H and 3C structures of SrIrO3 have been most studied for acid OER [46,48–50]. 6H-SrIrO3 is characterized by a monoclinic distortion with an overall structure analogous to the well-known hexagonal BaTiO3-type structure, as illustrated in Fig. 2 b [46]. On the other hand, 3C-SrIrO3 is composed of corner-sharing IrO6 octahedra adopting a close-packed, pseudo-cubic structure (Fig. 2e) [48]. Based on reported OER overpotentials for these systems (Table 1), the 6H-SrIrO3 structure generally exhibits lower OER activity (higher OER overpotentials) than 3C-SrIrO3. However, it is worth noting that a direct comparison among the OER activity data reported for the same SrIrO3 polymorphs is obscured by the differences in relevant reaction parameters (e.g., substrate, electrolyte). Moreover, the potential for oxide surface reconstruction presents restrictions in deriving accurate structure–activity relations. For instance, the high activity reported for epitaxially grown 3C-SrIrO3 thin films was associated with the in situ formation of an active IrOx-rich surface during OER that resulted from Sr leaching [49]. The intricacies associated with obtaining consistent trends in these dynamic systems led to a reverse behavior for the same systems reported by Yang et al., where 6H-SrIrO3 was shown to be more active than its 3C-SrIrO3 counterpart [46]. The enhancement in OER activity was postulated to stem from the presence of Ir atoms in the face-sharing octahedra of 6H-SrIrO3, as these atoms have relatively weaker O binding as compared to the Ir atoms in the corner-sharing octahedra of 3C-SrIrO3. Furthermore, most of the reported studies on SrIrO3 showed that the 6H polymorph exhibited the highest OER stability because of the low Sr dissolution [46,50]. Using inductively coupled plasma (ICP) spectroscopy, the Sr dissolution was quantified to be ~1–4 wt% and 24 wt% for 6H-SrIrO3 and 3C-SrIrO3, respectively [46,50]. This is consistent with the reported higher OER activity of 3C-SrIrO3 [49], as discussed above, resulting from the oxide surface restructuring under acidic conditions induced by substantial Sr dissolution leading to the formation of a highly active IrOx-rich surface. 2.3 Higher-order perovskite electrocatalysts Superposition of simple perovskite unit cells results in the formation of more complex, high-order perovskites, such as double (A2B’BO6) (Fig. 2c) and A-site ordered quadruple (AA’3B4O12) perovskites; additional classes of mixed metal oxides with potential for catalyzing OER [36,51,52,55]. For the double perovskites, the A and B’ sites are generally occupied by lanthanide or alkali earth metal cations, while the B site is composed of transition metal cations (commonly Ir or Ru for OER). The A and B-site occupants of quadruple perovskites are similar to those of the simple perovskites, however, incorporation of a smaller A’ transition metal cation (such as Cu) than A is needed for structural stability [52,56,57]. For Ir-based double perovskites, a compositional dependent activity trend of Ba2NdIrO6 > Ba2PrIrO6 ~ Ba2LaIrO6 > Ba2YIrO6 > Ba2TbIrO6 ~ Ba2CeIrO6 was observed in 0.1 M HClO4 (Table 1) [51]. The high OER activities (reported as the overpotential at 10 mA/cm2 geo) of Ba2NdIrO6, Ba2PrIrO6 and Ba2YIrO6 were linked to the lattice strain effects in the IrO6 octahedra induced by the smaller size of Nd, Pr (among the lanthanide series) and Y. The resulting strain led to weakening of the adsorption energies of the oxygenated intermediates on Ir in these oxides as compared to that on IrO2. Based on one-hour of chronopotentiometric testing, Ba2PrIrO6 and Ba2YIrO6 were shown to exhibit comparable stability to IrO2, while the other oxides lost their activity. However, post-reaction surface and bulk characterization of Ba2PrIrO6 showed that the Ba and the B’-site cation leached out of the structure during OER, enriching the oxide surface with active IrOx [48,49]. This phenomenon of formation of active IrOx through oxide reconstruction and ion leaching, has also been reported for other double perovskites such as La2LiIrO6 and Sr2FeIrO6 [36,55]. While different formation mechanisms for surface IrOx were proposed, it was found that the initial low activity of Sr2FeIrO6 gradually improved within 50 cycles of OER, due to the electrodeposition of the dissolved Ir ions on the oxide surface forming more active IrOx catalytic centers [55]. For the quadruple perovskites, Miao et al., [52] reported that CaCu3Ru4O12 exhibited higher activity than the previously reported Ru-based perovskites [47,58]. For instance, at 1.5 V vs. RHE, it was shown to exhibit ~ 53-fold improvement in BET-normalized activity as compared to Sr1-xNaxRuO3 (x = 0.05, 0.1) and a 3-fold improvement as compared to SrRuO3. Moreover, this oxide demonstrated significantly longer stability (18 times) than Sr0.90Na0.10RuO3, which already exhibits a stability improvement from SrRuO3 [47]. The performance of CaCu3Ru4O12 was ascribed to its structure, where Ru in a quadruple perovskite framework was postulated to have weaker Ru-O binding strengths, as compared to Ru in RuO2, thereby improving OER activity. Additionally, its stability was attributed to the complex nature of its quadruple perovskite structure that minimized the leaching of the metal cations, particularly those in the A-site, which are prone to leaching within the OER potential window. 2.4 Other mixed ionic-electronic conducting metal oxide electrocatalysts Layered, first-series Ruddlesden-Popper (R-P) (A2BO4) (Fig. 2d) and Sr4PtO6 type structure oxides have also been studied for acid OER [50]. For instance, the OER performance of strontium iridates (Sr2IrO4 and Sr4IrO6) in these two type structures was systematically compared, while keeping the A-site cation (Sr) unchanged [50]. Sr2IrO4 is characterized by a first-series R-P structure composed of alternating SrIrO3 perovskite and SrO layers, while Sr4IrO6 by a Sr4PtO6 type structure composed of alternating IrO6 octahedra layers separated by Sr cations. It was found that Sr2IrO4 exhibited higher activity than Sr4IrO6 based on normalization of the current per BET surface area, while also demonstrating better stability during a span of six-hour testing. However, leaching was detected in these iridates analogous to the observation from earlier studies on strontium iridate perovskites, resulting in surface IrOx catalytic centers [49]. The activity of the formed surface IrOx was highly dependent on the original oxide structures (i.e., IrO6 octahedra position and interconnectivity) [50]. Pyrochlore-type oxides (A2B2O7, where A is typically a rare-earth or p-block metal cation (i.e, Bi, Pb, Y, lanthanides); and B is a transition metal cation [59]) generally with a face-centered cubic phase (Fig. 2f) are another family of mixed ionic-electronic conducting oxides with potential for acid OER [53,54,60–66]. Similar to the oxide classes mentioned above, they can accommodate versatile and flexible compositions, which can be used as levers to tune their OER activity. A-site metal cations in these oxides extensively studied for acid OER include Bi [65], Pb [63], and rare earth metal cations [54,60,61], while B-site cation compositions mainly focus on Ir and Ru due to their intrinsic activity for OER [53,61]. With respect to B-site compositional effects, it was reported that an increase in OER activity was observed as the Ru content increased in (Na0.33Ce0.67)2(Ir1-xRux)2O7-δ (0 ≤ x ≤ 1) using 0.5 M H2SO4 [64]. Furthermore, (Na0.33Ce0.67)2Ru2O7-δ exhibited a 7-fold increase in mass-activity (i.e. mA/cm2 g oxide) at 1.5 V vs. RHE when compared to (Na0.33Ce0.67)2Ir2O7-δ. This suggested that the B-site Ru was more active than Ir in pyrochlores, consistent with the higher activity of Ru as compared to Ir in their rutile-type oxides (RuO2 and IrO2) [20]. In terms of B-site substitution, the activity of Y2Ru2O7-δ was reported to increase via substitution with Y (Y2[Ru1.6Y0.4]O7-δ) in 0.1 M perchloric acid solution [53]. A 6-fold improvement in mass-activity (i.e. mA/cm2 g oxide) at 1.5 V vs. RHE was observed when the B-site composition of Y2Ru2O7-δ was modified to Y2[Ru1.6Y0.4]O7-δ. The increase in activity was correlated to the induced oxygen deficiency in the structure from Y substitution, which led to mixed Ru4+/Ru5+ oxide states and an optimized energy band structure between the Ru-4d and O-2p states. In the case of A-site effects, a systematic OER study on the A-site lanthanide series of Ln2Ir2O7-δ (Ln = Ho, Tb, Gd, Nd, and Pr) in O2-saturated 0.1 M HClO4 showed a gradual increase in OER activity when the A-site changed from a small size Ho3+ ion to a large size Pr3+ cation [66]. This led to OER activities (reported as the BET surface area-normalized current densities at an overpotential of 0.3 V) for Nd2Ir2O7 and Pr2Ir2O7 being 14 and 39 times higher, respectively, than that of Ho2Ir2O7. The enhanced activity was linked to two factors [66]. One was associated with the improved electronic conductivity from an insulator-semimetal-metal transition observed as the A-site metal cation changed from Ho to Tb, Gd, Nd and Pr. Ho2Ir2O7 and Tb2Ir2O7 exhibited insulating behavior, while Nd2Ir2O7 and Pr2Ir2O7 exhibited metallic conductor properties. The second factor was associated with the higher distortion of IrO6 octahedra with an increase in the size of the A-site metal cation, as evidenced by the observed larger Ir-O-Ir angles in these pyrochlore-type oxides. This resulted in a weakened electron correlation and an enhanced Ir-O covalency, consequently leading to a strong hybridization of Ir-5d and O-2p orbitals, which played a key role in the improved OER activity. Additionally, amongst the non-lanthanide A-site compositions in A2Ir2O7 oxides where A = Bi, Y, Pb and their mixtures, it was reported that Y2Ir2O7 exhibited the highest activity (reported as BET surface area-normalized current densities at 1.525 V vs. RHE) for OER in 0.1 M HClO4 [62]. An initial increase in the activity with an increase in the number of OER cycles was observed for Y-containing pyrochlores, induced by the formation of active OER IrOx from Y leaching, similar to the cases presented above for the Ir-based mixed metal oxides [36,39,51,55]. 3 Oxide electrocatalyst stability in acid OER Stability of oxide electrocatalysts in acid OER conditions is a major bottleneck for their practical application [7,12,21,24,25]. Significant effort has focused on evaluating the stability of mixed metal oxides, however inconsistent approaches are used due to lack of standardized protocols and metrics. One approach involves the evaluation of the overpotential change as a function of testing time at a constant OER current density of 10 mA/cm2 geo (Table 2 ), which signifies the approximate current density expected for a 10% efficient solar-to-fuels conversion device under 1 sun illumination [67]. This widely used approach provides insights regarding the electrocatalyst stability relevant for preliminary screening in an accelerated timeframe. For instance, a clear compositional-dependent change in activity as a function of testing time was observed for Ba2B’IrO6, with B’ compositions of Pr and Y (Ba2PrIrO6 and Ba2YIrO6) exhibiting much lower changes in overpotential than the others, suggesting higher stability under acid OER conditions [51]. To visualize the overpotential change, Fig. 3 a shows a plot of OER overpotentials at t = 0 and after a period of two hours as an example, where the diagonal line signifies unchanged overpotential. Hence, the closer the reported performance is to this line, the more stable the electrocatalyst. Most of the reported oxides in Fig. 3a deviate from this line, implying an initial instability during acid OER. To understand the reason of this deviation, characterization of electrolyte solution via ICP to detect metal cation leaching from the oxides is often performed [48,51]. Fig. 3b shows the reported OER overpotential change and Ir dissolution after stability testing on selected Ir-based oxides, as examples. Interestingly, among these oxides, no obvious correlation between the extent of Ir leaching and the stability in terms of overpotential change is observed. For instance, IrOx exhibited the largest deviation from the stable diagonal line in Fig. 3a, however, the measured amount of Ir leaching in the electrolyte solution was relatively low compared to the mixed metal oxides. This may arise from artifacts induced from the leaching of other metal cations in mixed oxides resulting in rich IrOx surfaces, which have been shown to be highly active for OER, thus compensating for the potential losses from Ir leaching. As such, the dynamic changes of the oxide surfaces make the stability evaluation based only on overpotential changes at a given current density challenging. To overcome the aforementioned challenge, a stability number (S-number) approach was proposed based on the ratio of the total evolved O2(g) and the dissolved oxide B-site precious metal cations (i.e., Ir in this study) during OER testing. The amount of O2 was determined using the total charge (Qtotal) extracted from voltammetry, while the dissolved Ir was quantified using an online inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) in a scanning flow cell [35]. Hence, the stability number is independent of the surface area of the catalyst, catalyst loading, or the number of active sites. When S-number was used to evaluate the stability of Ir-based mixed metal oxides, it was found that the Ba-based double perovskites (i.e., Ba2YIrO6, and Ba2PrIrO6) exhibited relatively similar S-numbers in the order of 10 4 . These were comparable to the measured S-number for SrIrO3 and one magnitude higher than the measured S-number for Ba2YIrO6. However, it was shown that crystalline IrO2 exhibited the highest S-number 10 6 among these Ir-based oxides, suggesting its highest stability, which was extrapolated to a catalytic lifetime of one year when considering operation under a constant mass current density of 0.2 A/mgIr [35]. This sets a potential lower bound of ~106 for the S-number window of stable OER electrocatalysts. However, when the S-number was extrapolated to predict the lifetime of oxides in a PEM electrolyzer, a difference larger than two orders of magnitude was found with the S-number underestimating the oxide stability. Thus, future research directions in refining this approach to properly account for the lifetime of the oxide in electrolyzers are needed. Generally, independent of the ways that stability of Ir and Ru-based mixed metal oxides for acid OER is determined, it is clear that the long-term stability still remains a challenge for these electrocatalysts. Although progress has been made in synthesizing these materials with lower Ir and Ru nominal content, dissolution of the metal cations presents an immediate challenge that needs to be addressed for serious discussion of practical implementation of these oxides in non-alkaline electrochemical devices. Therefore, understanding the dissolution process is critical toward development of robust oxide electrocatalyst for acid OER. To this end, a proposed mechanism for Ir dissolution from Ir-based oxides has been reported based on the Ir species generated during OER [68,69]. In the case of Ir dissolution from IrO2, it was suggested that the decomposition of IrO2OH species that formed from water dissociation on IrO2 initiated Ir dissolution [68]. The decomposition of IrO2OH species was shown to be dependent on the electrode potential. At relatively low potentials, IrO2OH decomposed to HIrO2 evolving 1/2 O2(g). Reaction of HIrO2 with a proton led to formation of Ir3+ species and water in solution. At high potentials (>1.6 V vs. RHE), IrO2OH species decomposed to IrO3, which further reacted with H2O to form IrO 4 2- . 4 Summary and outlook Mixed metal oxides composed of highly active Ir/Ru cations have shown potential for OER in acidic media, however they are largely challenged by their dynamic nature under these conditions that often leads to limited long-term stability. Generally, IrO2, RuO2, and their 3d metal substituted counterparts have been the most studied metal oxides for OER. Largely, two main factors contribute to the activity improvements of Ir-based oxides: (i) distortions in the IrO6 octahedra induced by substitutions with secondary metals tuning oxygen binding on Ir, and (ii) leaching of the secondary metal leading to the creation of highly active surface IrOx catalytic sites. Recent increase in interest for using mixed ionic-electronic conducting oxides (i.e., perovskites and pyrochlores) to catalyze acid OER has stemmed from their flexible compositions and versatile crystal structures, providing a large design space for tuning OER performance. With the large compositional space of mixed metal oxides, activity descriptors based on binding energies of OER intermediates have been proposed. However, they are limited to oxides that remain unchanged under OER conditions, which often is not the case. Metal cation leaching is a commonly observed phenomenon during acid OER among various classes of mixed metal oxides. While in some cases, this is shown to generate more catalytically active surface species, it presents significant challenge for the oxide structural stability. Thus, proper evaluation of oxide stability, even on highly active oxides, is key toward development of design principles for identification of robust OER electrocatalysts for practical long-term applications. The fact that metal ions dissolve suggests that surface sites are dynamic in nature, which is largely different from the traditional view of heterogenous electrocatalysis, that assumes immobile surface active sites in constant contact with mobile reactant and product species. Thus, the understanding of the mechanism that governs these dynamic catalytic structures is fairly limited, rendering such knowledge central to the development of approaches to enhance oxide stability. As a first step toward developing an in-depth understanding of the dynamic structure of oxides under acid OER conditions, approaches based on the thermodynamics of these systems, such as development of Pourbaix diagrams for these oxides under different pHs and potentials generated using a combination of theoretical/experimental calculations, can be -instrumental in understanding the factors that govern metal cation dissolution [55,70]. These diagrams can also facilitate high-throughput computational screening for identification of promising oxides that exhibit either limited metal cation leaching, or restructure to catalytically more active surfaces under reaction conditions. To capture structural evolution of the mixed metal oxides during acid OER, ab initio molecular dynamic (AIMD) simulations are shown to be more insightful [71]. Nevertheless, given the complexity associated with the dynamic nature of the oxide surface structures under OER conditions, a combination of experimental and theoretical techniques (i.e., in situ X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS), in situ X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), density functional theory (DFT), AIMD, along with high resolution electron microscopy and spectroscopy) are needed to shed light on the evolution of the catalysts and active sites under reaction conditions. Application of such in situ spectroscopic approaches, i.e., high-pressure photoelectron spectroscopy (HP-XPS), can provide insights on the changes in the oxidation state and concentration of oxide elements near the surface region as a function of operating conditions. In situ HP-XPS has been successfully applied to electrochemical studies involving solid–liquid interfaces under similar acidic environments [72–74]. Further, in situ XAS studies can provide insights on the evolution of the electronic structure of the oxide under reaction conditions. While XAS is mainly a bulk technique, it has been successfully used to shed light on the dynamic nature of active sites in perovskites in alkaline environments [75,76]. Such in situ spectroscopic insights will be key at developing the appropriate advanced theoretical models to best describe the nature of active surfaces in these complex oxide systems. Surface oxide structure information can also benefit from imaging using scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) in combination with selected area electron diffraction (SAED). By indexing the d-spacing obtained in STEM imaging to the SAED patterns, surface facets can be identified and confirmed. However, given the dynamic nature of these oxides under reaction conditions, studies with electrodes exposed to various potentials are necessary. We caution that systematic analysis with STEM is often challenged by the complex nature of the composite electrodes and artifacts arising from oxide surface restructuring under a high energy electron beam. Isotopically labeled kinetic studies coupled with online gas analysis via mass spectrometry is another key approach in unearthing mechanistic details regarding acid OER on mixed metal oxides. For example, such 18O2 labeled studies on IrO2 have demonstrated that lattice oxygen can participate in the catalytic cycle of OER under acidic environments [34,77]. Furthermore, studies with isotopic labelled metal cations in mixed metal oxides (for ex: 191Ir) coupled with online ICP-MS studies can provide valuable insights on the mechanism that governs dissolution and redeposition of metal cations [55,78]. Such isotopic labeling approaches have been successfully used for investigating the dynamic nature of Ni/Co-Fe-O(OH) in alkaline media using isotopically labeled 57Fe cations [79]. An important aspect that is largely overlooked in the acid OER literature is the potential effect of the leached metal ions on other cell components of an electrolyzer. This is due to the fact that most reported studies are limited to well-controlled rotating electrode systems in a bath of liquid electrolyte. Re-deposition of the leached metal ions onto other cell components might arise as a significant issue when these catalytic systems are used in electrolyzer cells. As such, future studies in this direction are key to properly evaluate this effect. Systematic evaluation of OER performance in rotating disk electrode (RDE) systems is challenged by the disconnect between laboratory protocols and practical electrolyzer design heuristics. An example of this disconnect is evident with the significant difference between the electrocatalyst stability predicted from the S-number measured in a laboratory-scale electrochemical half-cell and the lifetime of the same electrocatalyst in an electrolyzer [35]. As such, standardized benchmarking protocols and target performance metrics for studies using RDE setups must be developed based on the criteria for testing in PEM electrolyzers. However, even for the case of full electrolyzer testing, these protocols and metrics are not systemic, leading to the lack of relevant standard testing protocols and target metrics that can be extrapolated to RDE testing. Moreover, a common benchmark catalyst is often not used in benchmarking OER performance of reported electrocatalysts. One reason for this could stem from variations in the measured OER activities of different commercial oxide electrocatalysts (i.e., IrO2) due to differences in testing conditions (e.g., electrode preparation, electrolyte). To circumvent this, standardized testing conditions are necessary to provide a baseline for consistency among different testing protocols. Thus, commercial IrO2 with BET surface areas ranging between 20–50 m2/g should be considered as benchmark catalysts, since IrO2 provides the best compromise between activity and stability. The OER activities of these benchmark catalysts should be consistently reported as BET surface area normalized currents at a specific potential (e.g., 1.5 V vs. RHE). OER stability benchmarking also lacks standardized protocols calling for a standardized accelerated stress test (AST). Extrapolating the AST protocol developed by the United States (U.S.) Department of Energy (DOE) for ORR to the OER potential window would be a feasible approach to investigate the stability of electrocatalysts for acid OER [80]. This protocol is similar to one of the two most common methods (i.e. potential cycling and chronopotentiometric holds) used in OER durability testing. The protocol would involve 30,000 cycles at a potential window of 1.4–1.75 V vs. RHE. The lower potential bound (1.4 V vs. RHE) is consistent with the testing conditions for commercial IrO2, a potential benchmark catalyst [28], while the 0.35 V potential window range is consistent with the one specified by the U.S. DOE AST benchmarking protocol for ORR. Potential cycling under this protocol can simulate the response of the electrocatalyst during startup-shutdown conditions, which is key for intermittent operation with renewable energy sources. In terms of target stability metrics, extrapolation from ORR metrics should be considered, in that stable catalysts should not lose more than 40% of their initial activity normalized by the catalyst mass or oxide BET surface area at the end of 30,000 cycles. Consistencies between testing protocols for ORR and OER also present avenues for testing reversible fuel cells. Ir- and Ru-based mixed metal oxides have by far gained the largest attention for acid OER, leaving non-precious mixed metal oxides largely unexplored. A few promising reports on non-precious mixed metal oxide for non-alkaline OER have hinted at their potential for this process [81,82]. However, further studies in this area are needed to fully explore their potential, as motivated by the large oxide space available for exploration and identification of active and stable non-alkaline (i.e. neutral pH and acid) OER electrocatalysts. Furthermore, the focus has mainly been on acid OER, leaving acid ORR by mixed metal oxides largely an uncharted territory. Acid ORR is especially important for development of bifunctional electrocatalysts for reversible electrochemical devices, which significantly simplifies their overall fabrication and enhances modularity [83,84]. Thus, future research directions should also include fundamental kinetic studies using mixed metal oxides for acid ORR. coredata.dc:description: Shaping the energy landscape through development of more efficient electrochemical energy conversion and storage devices requires significant advancements in the catalysis of key electrochemical processes involving oxygen. This is especially the case for the oxygen evolution reaction (OER), which is largely challenged by the cost-ineffectiveness of the best performing electrocatalysts (i.e., Ru, Ir), along with their limited stability under acidic conditions. This presents a roadblock in the development of robust acid-based polymer exchange membrane electrochemical systems, currently the most advanced technologies for electrochemical energy conversion. Approaches such as dilution of Ru/Ir into flexible mixed metal oxide frameworks have been used as alternative strategies in designing robust OER electrocatalysts. Herein, we discuss the state of research in this area and detail the effect of the composition and structure of mixed metal oxides on their acidic OER activity and stability. Future directions for developing mixed metal oxide electrocatalysts suitable for acidic electrochemical environments are devised.
coredata.dc:title: Oxygen evolution electrocatalysis using mixed metal oxides under acidic conditions: Challenges and opportunities
